I think the connectors are a better source of gold. The gold is to create an oxide-free surface for the mating surfaces of the connectors. So the PCB may have connectors with gold on them too. High speed cables and PCBs will probably have gold. Cheap appliance stuff will probably have 0 gold.
Chips with a lot of pins should have a good amound of gold; ever pin needs a short piece of gold wire to connect the pin to the lead-frame of the chip.

I usually put the aqua regia beaker into a warm water bath to speed up the reaction.

I use urea (which is very cheap) to bring up the pH, and then precipitate with warmed metabisulfite solution. Warming the neutralized gold chloride and metabisulfite, I found, caused almost instantaneous precipitation of all the gold into a sponge-form, which is then very easy to recover.

You can also use dilute nitric acid for the initial cleaning of the boards.  Weak nitric acid easily removes copper and nickel, but won't touch gold, platinum, palladium, or rhodium at all.  It will dissolve silver, but so does HCl and peroxide.

AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE AGE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Seriously, the older the scrap the more gold they use in a lot of cases. Motherboards from old servers cracked down into small pieces can yield a lot. I'm talking antique servers though, like late 80s, early 90s. I'm no expert in gold recovery but I know that much from being a bit of a computer/electronics expert. Only RAM seems to use steadily more gold as time goes on. The stuff you can get for the least money with the highest gold will probably be vintage servers, because far fewer people are interested in owning an antique server with no practical use than, say, an old pre-2000s personal computer. The things to avoid are the kinds of scrap with inflated value, or that could still be used for something practical. A lot of post 2000s computer parts end up in less wealthy countries as part of an actual computer, and my town even has a recycling program for computers. They have a reusable area but computers all get taken and shipped off to India, or Thailand or something. If people there are willing to buy junk computers in bulk, there's a big resale business on eBay for stuff that actually works. So in a way, it's more economics than tech. The older the stuff is, the less technology was in use at the time. The stuff that was being used by large businesses was sturdier and often overbuilt, but consumer stuff was often pretty bad by comparison. As time has gone on, things have reversed. Instead of keeping old technology businesses constantly upgrade their web severs, so they're build differently because the world also had a finite amount of gold. Higher demand means people need to be more careful when using it in a design. But back in the 90's and early 2000s, gold wasn't as expensive. If you look at a timeline of gold prices, offset it by about 6 months and you'll have a perfect timetable of how much gold is used in electronics. Buy stuff that was being rolled out at the lowest points on your new graph, and you'll get a better return. RAM is the exception, hence the global DRAM shortage as some have called it. That's not the only reason but it's part of it. I'm not putting any of my money into this but this was interesting and it was worth taking a few moments of my time to look into this a bit.

A point on the first part of the procedure: Dissolution of copper/nickel by the muriatic/peroxide solution is not necessarily slow: If one uses concentrated HCl (maxes-out at 37% but you don't need to go this high) and concentrated peroxide (you can find commercial-grade peroxide up to 50% strong), the reaction is so strong that the amount shown in the video would boil out of the beaker in a lot less than a minute (or crack the beaker!). Using a weaker solution  would still completely dissolve the copper & nickel off the PCBs in a few minutes. One should mind the generated hot HCl mist though: NOT lung-friendly!

In step 1 it would be cheaper to only bubble air through the hydrogen chloride, instead of using hydrogen peroxide. To get it started a bit quicker just add a few drops of peroxide and perhaps a bit of copper, like old electricity wires. You can easily reuse the copper chloride between batches to cut down costs even further. Add a bit of ammonium chloride to further increase the speed. It'll increase in strength every time you use it. Bubble air in between uses to regenerate the solution.

It's how I personally etch PCBs, but would work great here too. I use a cheap $5 aquarium pump from eBay with a piece of PE tubing. I sealed the end by melting it together and pierced hundreds of tiny holes with a hot needle in the section that goes underwater. Regeneration of a fully spent 5 liter batch of copper chloride takes about a week in my case. If the solution becomes fully saturated you can just add more hydrogen chloride, and later on even recover the copper for profit.
